repnme.cdata!: India - Chhattisgarh District Rural Poverty Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Chhattisgarh District
            Rural Poverty Project for India were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome
            was substantial, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a focused and
            participatory livelihoods approach through organized
            beneficiary groups can provide quick and tangible income
            results and improve well-being of poor rural households, and
            as a result contribute to their improved status in the
            community. There needs to be a strong technical support,
            especially in the case of marginalized groups who are
            exploring new livelihoods strategies. The length of a
            project needs to be long enough to allow for proper
            sequencing of activities first participatory identification
            and mobilization of the poor and formation of the
            institutions of the poor, then asset creation and
            aggregation through federations and then for innovations and
            building of local capacities. Direct control of funds, and a
            demand-driven process for investment decisions by
            beneficiaries, is critical for the empowerment of the poor,
            and to make sure resulting livelihoods sub-projects are
            suitable to the capacities, resources and social relations
            of poor community members. However for sustaining and
            developing such livelihoods it is important that funding
            support is matched by very good technical advice and linkage
            development. Targeting needs a structured, locally
            appropriate and participatory approach to wealth ranking.
            This needs to be well prepared, communicated, transparently
            and fairly implemented, and consistently applied statewide.
            Social accountability mechanisms need to be introduced at
            the community level, to ensure compliance through
            self-monitoring and peer pressure.

repnme.cdata!: India - Chhattisgarh District Rural Poverty Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Chhattisgarh District Rural Poverty Project is to improve
            opportunities for the poor and vulnerable, especially women
            and tribals, to meet their own social and economic
            development objectives. To achive this, the project creates
            infrastructure and income opportunities for the rural poor;
            empowers active groups of disadavanteged people; and
            supports village governments in becoming more responsive and
            effective in assisting them. There are two main project
            components. Component 1 focuses on six main activities: 1)
            human resource development for project stakeholders to build
            skills and change behavior through orientation, reward, and
            performance appraisal, and supply-driven and demand-driven
            training; 2) strengthening of "panchayats" to
            develop training programs; 3) formation and strengthening of
            organizations to recruit and build the capacity of
            nongovernmental organizations and project facilitation
            teams; 4) communication and information to ensure that the
            project and its rules are disseminated to all target
            beneficiaries appropriately; 5) monitoring and learning and
            special studies to support information gathering; and 6)
            project administration. Component 2 comprises community
            investments, including matching grants for community
            invrstments, matching grants for "panchayat plans,
            village funds that are entirely financed by community
            contributions and that finance operation and maintenance of
            village infrastructure, and innovation funds.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Chhattisgarh District Rural Poverty
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Chhattisgarh District Rural Poverty Project comprises both
            the environmental management framework, and the report on
            public consultations, and examines how the project might
            affect human resource, and stocks of natural resources, to
            then identify mitigation measures that minimize the negative
            environmental impacts of the project. Through a screening
            process, four categories of subprojects will be identified,
            suggesting the appropriate environmental mitigation.
            Overall, mitigation stipulates the following: to control
            soil erosion, protective barriers will be installed,
            including gravel exposure, while laboratory tests will be
            conducted to identify the presence of toxic chemicals, to
            prevent soil pollution; groundwater depletion will be
            controlled through the installation of bore wells, allowing
            the measurement of water levels, and, laboratory analysis
            will be conducted to prevent water pollution, and control
            bacteria that may affect health, while water logging will be
            surveyed; deforestation, and loss of biodiversity,
            particularly medicinal plants, will be surveyed, in order to
            be re-planted following project implementation. Construction
            designs will determine adequate spillways, and downstream
            slopes to prevent soil erosion, as well as dam safety
            measures, which will be supervised by qualified engineers.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Chhattisgarh District Rural Poverty
            Project : tribal development strategy

abstracts.cdata!:
This strategy document broadly outlines
            the context of socioeconomic, and development status of
            tribal groups in the project area, and presents a plan to
            address these within the framework of the project. It
            presents an overview of tribal communities in the area, the
            legal and policy framework regarding tribal issues in
            Chhattisgarh, and the major problems, and concerns tribal
            people face in securing access to revenue land, and to
            forests. Fundamental strategies stipulate: fair
            participation, and representation at all levels of the
            project, with a view to influence its decisions, and
            outcomes for the tribal constituents; ensured protection of
            social, economic, and cultural interest of tribal
            communities in project interventions, among both the tribal,
            and the non-tribal groups; overcome structural constraints
            to poverty, and deprivation among tribal people, through
            direct socioeconomic interventions, as well as induced
            actions under other available public resources, and legal
            provisions of the Government; optimize community
            productivity, and that of privately held land, forest, and
            livestock resources among tribal people, with a view to
            primarily ensure food security, and generate sustainable
            surplus; enhance options for labor, and for improved returns
            from labor, as a growing basis for livelihood activity for
            largest number of tribal families in the region; and,
            rigorous capacity building of tribal people at the
            village-level organizations, and at its leadership level, to
            be able to plan, prioritize, and place appropriate demands
            on project services, and resources.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Chhattisgarh District Rural Poverty
            Project : tribal development strategy

abstracts.cdata!:
This strategy document broadly outlines
            the context of socioeconomic, and development status of
            tribal groups in the project area, and presents a plan to
            address these within the framework of the project. It
            presents an overview of tribal communities in the area, the
            legal and policy framework regarding tribal issues in
            Chhattisgarh, and the major problems, and concerns tribal
            people face in securing access to revenue land, and to
            forests. Fundamental strategies stipulate: fair
            participation, and representation at all levels of the
            project, with a view to influence its decisions, and
            outcomes for the tribal constituents; ensured protection of
            social, economic, and cultural interest of tribal
            communities in project interventions, among both the tribal,
            and the non-tribal groups; overcome structural constraints
            to poverty, and deprivation among tribal people, through
            direct socioeconomic interventions, as well as induced
            actions under other available public resources, and legal
            provisions of the Government; optimize community
            productivity, and that of privately held land, forest, and
            livestock resources among tribal people, with a view to
            primarily ensure food security, and generate sustainable
            surplus; enhance options for labor, and for improved returns
            from labor, as a growing basis for livelihood activity for
            largest number of tribal families in the region; and,
            rigorous capacity building of tribal people at the
            village-level organizations, and at its leadership level, to
            be able to plan, prioritize, and place appropriate demands
            on project services, and resources.
